rounds.response:
I have King-high (K♠ 4♠) on a rainbow flop of A♠ 3♦ 2♦. The ace is out there, which is a problem because any ace in my opponent’s hand beats me, and 34 combos just made a wheel straight. Because the flop is small-connected and paired-looking, my actual equity with king-high is low versus the range of hands that will happily fire or continue. I’m out of position and have to act first for the rest of the hand. 

Checking and hoping to get to showdown cheaply is my best option here—every bet I make will get called or raised by better hands and fold out worse ones.

[Check]

rounds.response:
[Fold]

I have King-high with a 4 kicker.  
- The board shows an Ace and four diamonds, so any flush beats me.  
- Every reasonable holding in the villain’s range (an Ace, a seven, or any diamond) has me beaten or drawing almost dead.  
Facing a strongly polarized 20-chip bet on the turn, I’m saving the 20 chips with a fold rather than getting value-cut.

rounds.response:
With the Ace-Ten offsuit from the big-blind position, this is the first reasonable hand I‘ve been dealt.  
My plan:

- Against a single opponent, A-10 is ahead of most of their limping / small-open range and it plays well post-flop.  
- We’re out of position, so a simple call keeps the pot small if we miss, but still builds value when we hit.  
- Folding is far too tight here, and with only 920 chips I don’t want to start bloating pots with 3-bet bluffs just yet.

[Call]

Let's evaluate the situation:

Hand 10 – Turn  
Visible board: 8♥ 9♥ A♣ K♣  
Pot: 100  
Your hand: 7♦ 9♣ → you have just one pair (nines) with the nut-flush draw already present on the board and a Broadway straight possible with every Q-T as well as any two-heart hand—none of which you have blockers against.

That means your pair of nines is now extremely weak. Checking behind on the flop was good; after the K♣ hits, you have no additional equity and multiple better hands already out there. The only play that makes sense from out of position is to check and likely give up. Betting or raising risks burning chips needlessly in a spot where you’re essentially bluff-catching with a very marginal holding.

[Check]
